headline.main: DIPLOMATIC CORRESPONDENCE.; Expenses of the American Legations Abroad.

docs.lead_paragraph: SIR: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of Nov. 4, 1851, (No. 17,) communicating a resolution adopted by the Senate on the 31st of Jan. last, and asking specific and accurate information respecting the expenses incident to my residence in my official character at Constantinople.

headline.main: FROM HAVANA.; The President's Message on Cuba--Affairs in Havana.

docs.lead_paragraph: With great respect for the opinions uttered with the gravity proper in a message of the Chief Magistrate of the Union, permit me to make a few side remarks, not particularly touching the general merit of the document, which we have had the pleasure of reading, although interdicted under the " misconception" of the Captain-Genoral of Cuba-General CANEDO.

byline.original: Correspondence of the New-York Daily Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Some changes of importance have recently taken place in the Board of Commissioners of Emigration. Mr. HICKS has resigned, on account of ill health, and the Governor has appointed CALER BARSTOW, Esq., to fill his place. JAMES L. MORRIS, Esq., has also resigned his position as Vice-President.

headline.main: OFFICIAL DOCUMENTS.; AMERICAN DIPLOMATIC SERVICE. Expenses of the several Delegation.

docs.lead_paragraph: Our Government, a few months since, issued a circular dispatch to several of our Ministers in Europe, asking of them information as to the expenses they were severally obliged to incur. To that circular, the following replies, which we copy from the Post, have been returned: Letter from Abbott Lawrence.

headline.main: ADDITIONAL FOREIGN EXTRACTS; PER STEAMER AFRICA.

docs.lead_paragraph: The London Standard, announcing the death of Rev. M. MARCUS, formerly Rector of the Church of St. George the Martyr, in this City adds: He came to this country about four years since, for the purpose of procuring means for the establishment of an Emigrants' Home in New-York, in which the poorer class of British emigrants should enjoy the advantages of shelter and religions instruction on their arrival in the United States.

docs.lead_paragraph: ARRIVAL OF THE CHERUKES.--The U. S. M. steamship Cherokee, Capt. Baxter, arrived at this port last evening from New-Orleans, vid Havana, with dates from the latter port to the 14th inst. No further difficulties were experienced by the Cherokee in entering Havana. Full and free communication with the shore was permitted, and the mails and passengers were received and landed quietly.

headline.main: LATER FROM HAVANA.; ARRIVAL OF THE BLACK WARRIOR. Capt. Grey--Earthquake--The Slave Trade--Execution--General News--Changes in the Tariff, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: The steamer Black Warrior, R. W. SHUFELDT, U.S.N., commander, arrived yesterday afternoon at half-past 3 o'clock, from Mobile from Havana, Left Mobile Bar at 8 P.M., on the 9th inst., and Havana on the 12th at 5 P.M.

headline.main: THREE DAYS LATER FROM EUROPE; ARRIVAL OF THE AFRICA. DECLARATION OF THE EMPIRE IN FRANCE. SPEECH OF THE EMPEROR. THE BUDGET IN ENGLAND. Speech of the Chancellor of the Exchequer. EXTRACTS FROM THE LONDON PRESS. CENERAL INTELLIGENCE. Dates-London and Liverpool, Dec. 4; Paris, 3. The Budget. Canal Across the Isthmus of Darien. Mr. Ingersoll at the St. Andrew's Dinner. Miscellaneous. FRANCE. Proclamation of the Empire. Napoleon III.'s Inaugural Speech. ALGERIA. BELGIUM Reduction of the Belgian Funds. HOLAND. Notice to reduce the Dutch Funds. SPAIN. ITALY. PRUSSIA. Opening of the Chambers. INDIA. The Capture of Procle. COMMERCIAL INTELLIGENCE. Breadstaffs and Provisions. Another Circular--Cotton and Grain. London Markets. American Stocks.

docs.lead_paragraph: The British and North American Mail steamship Africa, from Liverpool, at noon, on Saturday, 4th inst., arrived at this port at 2 1/2 o'clock P. M., yesterday . The new screw steamer Andes, the first of the Cunard Company's steamships between Liverpool and Chagres. via United States ports, was to sail from Liverpool, Wednesday, Dec. 8, for NewYork, and is expected to anticipate the mail usually received via Southampton.

headline.main: WASHINGTON.; Health of Mr. King -- The Kentucky Case -- Atboni. &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: The precarious condition of Mr. KING'S health is a topic of anxious interest with his friends. The fact that the Senate went into Executive Session for the purpose of talking over the steps necessary to be taken in view of his inability to attend its sittings, shows the studious efforts which were made to keep from the public a knowledge of his true condition. Of course, all such attempts are futile.

byline.original: Correspondence of the New-York Daily Times

headline.main: MORAL AND RELIGIOUS.; Church and Missionary Intelligence.

docs.lead_paragraph: A meeting of the Clergy and Laity of the Protestant Episcopal Church was held in the vestryroom of Trisity Church, for the purpose of hearing the report of the Committee on the Mission at the Five Points. Right Rev. Dr. WAINWRIGHT presided.
